comments.text:
Hello,

I've joined Bugzilla to report exactly this!

When I reply to messages (single or long conversations) I often 'clean up' the previous messages. This can involve any/all of the following:

Remove all indents (select all, click the Outdent Text button a few times)
Delete unnecessary signature blocks, virus-scan notices, etc.
Get rid of unnecesary spacing (select all, change the paragraph format to body text)
Make font sizes readable (select all, Format>Size>Medium)
Make fonts consistent (select all, Format>Remove All Text Styles)

You'd think that after all this you had nothing but plain text left, but the spell checker nearly always finds underlying html code.

The only way I've found to stop this is to copy and paste the email into a text only editor (I use notepad) and back.

It's perhaps not a huge problem, but looking at the size of messages, there must be an awful lot of stuff hidden. A message that has, say, 3kb of text in it could be 30kb before running through a notepad filter.

In Outlook I used to set the message format to plain text, and then set it back to html if I wanted to add any new formatting. Thunderbird obviously doesn't actually convert the message to plain text when you do this, because some formatting (like bold fonts) seems to be retained.

WYS is definitely NOT WYG!

Piers.
